metadata.titleEn: Glacierized river basin dataset in China and the surrounding areas（1950-2020）
metadata.description: Mountain glaciers are important freshwater resources in Western China and its surrounding areas. It is at the drainage basin scale that mountain glaciers provide meltwater that humans exploit and utilize. Therefore, the determination of glacierized river basins is the basis for the research on glacier meltwater provisioning functions and their services. Based on the Randolph glacier inventory 6.0,  Chinese Glacier Inventories, China's river basin classifications (collected from the Data Centre for Resources and Environmental Sciences, Chinese Academy of Sciences), and global-scale HydroBASINS (www.hydrosheds.org), the following dataset was generated by the intersection between river basins and glacier inventory: (1) Chinese glacierized macroscale and microscale river basins; (2) International glacierized macroscale river basin fed by China’s glaciers; (3) Glacierized macroscale river basin data across High Mountain Asia.  This data takes the common river basin boundaries in China and the globe into account, which is poised to provide basic data for the study of historical and future glacier water resources in China and its surrounding areas.
metadata.instructions:
File naming: different types of the glacierized river basins are stored in the shape files.
Method and usage: The data can be read by ArcGIS, Matlab, Python, etc.

background: China has the largest area of glaciers situated within the middle- and low-latitude areas worldwide. Rapid changes in mountain glaciers across western China in the last decades have not only affected glacial runoff and hazards but also had profound impacts on ecosystems and socioeconomic activities in the extensive cold and arid regions of Asia and even beyond. Mountain glaciers are a key part of Earth’s cryosphere, and they can be highly sensitive to even small climatic fluctuations. In recent decades, climate warming has accelerated and led to a widespread shrinking of glaciers globally, which not only affects river runoff, mountain hazards and global sea level but also has potentially severe implications for regional ecosystems, socioeconomic activities, and human cultural and spiritual aspects. China has the largest number of glaciers across the middle- and low-latitude areas worldwide. Recent studies have shown that there are a total of 48,571 glaciers with an area of approximately 51,840.1 km², which account for 22.5% of the number and 7.3% of the area of glaciers globally in the up-to-date Randolph Glacier Inventory (RGI 6.0; 215,547 glaciers with a total area of 705,738.8 km²). Glaciers in China are mainly distributed in the high mountains of the western region. Approximately 248.2 million people (2015) depend in part on glacial meltwater in China. Especially in northwestern arid inland basins with high water stress, including the Tarim, Junggar, Turpan-Hami, and Qaidam basins and Hexi Corridor, meltwater from glaciers in the Tien Shan, Qilian, and the northern Kunlun Mountains plays an extremely important role in the formation and development of local socioecological systems. In addition, the glaciers on the Chinese TP and the Altai, and western Chinese Tien Shan Mountains also supply drainage runoff for many large international river basins with highly dense populations, such as the Brahmaputra, Ganges, Indus, Ob, Lake Balkash, Mekong, and Salween River basins. In recent decades, numerous studies have investigated China’s glacier changes and their influencing factors using a range of approaches, including in-situ measurements, remote sensing, and modeling. These studies have indicated that an overall retreating trend in glaciers has been observed in China during the past half-century. The glacial recession in China has profound impacts on the socioecological systems of China, as well as other regions of Asia and even the world, through material and energy flows. However, in contrast to the overall glacier mass loss and area/volume shrinkage, changes in glaciers in the western Kunlun Mountains, Karakoram, and Pamirs have been very anomalous in recent decades. Their glacier mass has lost very little or has even grown, glacier area and volume has presented no significant changes, and a considerable number of glaciers have advanced or surged, which is described as the “Karakoram Anomaly” and has received increasing attention.
research objective: This study re-analyzes the first and second Chinese Glacier Inventories (CGI-1 and CGI-2) and summarizes available in-situ observation-based studies on glacier mass balance and length to provide a spatially explicit and coherent national-scale assessment of glacier changes and associated influencing factors in recent decades. We connect the glaciers between CGI-1 (from the 1950s to the 1980s) and CGI-2 (from the 2000s to the 2010s) one by one to explore the area, volume, and Equilibrium Line Altitude (ELA) changes at both the individual glacier and river basin scales for the first time. To address these gaps, we first conducted a spatially explicit and coherent national-scale assessment of glacier changes by establishing a one-to-one correspondence between glaciers from CGI-1 to CGI-2. Second, we further provided an overview of in-situ observed glacier mass balance and length changes in China. Finally, the influencing factors of glacier evolution encompassing climatology and climate change, as well as glacial morphology and topographic condition, were comprehensively analysed along with a review of previous relevant studies.
challenges: However, due to the inaccessibility of most glaciated areas and shortages of long-term human and financial resources, only a few glaciers have been observed, and very few glaciers have been continuously monitored as reference glaciers in the world. However, these studies did not give attention to individual glacial evolution between the two periods. Some glaciers emerged in CGI-2, but statistics were not available for CGI-1 because of the uncertainty of visual interpretation, which may have led to a lower estimate of retreat.
methods: In this study, we first removed 6201 glaciers from the CGI-1 and CGI-2 datasets because their real-time information was not updated but compiled, after which 40,176 and 42,370 glaciers remained, respectively. Then, we established the correspondence between glaciers from CGI-1 to CGI-2 following different kinds of evolutionary trajectories of modern mountain glaciers. We made an effort to discriminate the different types of glacier evolution based on glacier boundaries in CGI-1 and CGI-2 one by one.
dataset: CGI-1 was established based on aerial photographs and topographic maps from the 1960s to 1980s combined with extensive field investigations, and 34 parameters (e.g., area and elevation, etc.) were recorded following the standard guidebook of the World Glacier Inventory. Finally, a total of 46,377 glaciers with an area of approximately 59,425.2 km² in China from the 1960s to 1980s were measured, compiled, and published with 21 books and about 200 attached maps in Chinese. CGI-2 updated glacier outlines and basic parameters of 85.5% of China’s glaciers based on Landsat TM/ETM+, ASTER, and Google Earth images from 2004 to 2011. The other 6201 glaciers (24.5%), with an area of 8753.5 km², are mainly located in the eastern Nyainqentanglha Mountains and western Hengduan Mountains, which are frequently cloudy and covered by snow year-round; thus, no high-quality visible images are available.
findings: The results show that the long-term area and volume changes in China’s glaciers during the area-weighted average period from CGI-1 (around 1969) to CGI-2 (around 2008) were 5.6%/decade and 5.3%/decade, respectively, with a mean ELA change of 12.5 m/decade. Approximately 17.2% of the total number of glaciers in CGI-1 disappeared, only 5.5% of the glaciers advanced, and the majority of glaciers decreased in size during the period between CGI-1 and CGI-2, which was characterized by a shrinkage in area and volume and a rise in ELA or division into multiple branches. In-situ observation-based analysis shows that glacier length has reduced since at least the 1960s on average, and their trends have accelerated since the 1990s. The negative trend of mass balance was slightly larger than that of the reference glaciers globally during 1960–2019, while the mean mass loss in any given decade was lower than that of the global mean. Climatic conditions, as reflected in annual mean temperature and precipitation, are the primary causes of different spatiotemporal patterns of glacier change. A significant positive correlation is observed between annual absolute area/volume changes and snowfall variations, and a significant negative correlation is found with rainfall variations, but there is no significant correlation between the indicators of air temperature and glacial changes at the river basin scale.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to monitor China's glaciers over several decades?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used to monitor China's glaciers involves the use of aerial photographs and topographic maps from the 1960s to 1980s combined with extensive field investigations, as well as Landsat TM/ETM+, ASTER, and Google Earth images from 2004 to 2011.

Example.Question: Please provide an example of a challenge faced when continuously monitoring glaciers in China over time.
Example.Answer: A challenge faced in continuously monitoring glaciers in China is the inaccessibility of most glaciated areas and shortages of long-term human and financial resources, which results in only a few glaciers being observed and very few being continuously monitored.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset that could be used to assess glacier changes and their influencing factors in China?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used to assess glacier changes and their influencing factors in China includes the CGI-1 and CGI-2 datasets, which provide glacier outlines and basic parameters based on different sources such as aerial photographs, topographic maps, Landsat, ASTER, and Google Earth images.

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'glacier inventory' in the context of glacial data collection and analysis?
Definition.Answer: A glacier inventory refers to a comprehensive and systematic collection of data about glaciers, including parameters such as area, elevation, and other relevant characteristics. It typically involves the use of aerial photographs, topographic maps, remote sensing technologies, and field investigations to measure and compile information about a large number of glaciers over a specified period.

Definition.Question: How is 'in-situ observation' defined in the context of studying glacier changes?
Definition.Answer: In-situ observation in the context of studying glacier changes refers to the direct and on-site collection of data regarding glaciers' physical properties, such as mass balance and length. This method involves monitoring and measuring glaciers directly in the field, which provides detailed and specific information about the glacier's condition and changes over time.

Comparison.Question: What similarities and differences exist between the challenges faced in collecting long-term glacier data and those encountered in monitoring other remote or inaccessible natural phenomena?
Comparison.Answer: Similar challenges in collecting long-term glacier data and monitoring other remote phenomena include inaccessibility of areas, shortages of long-term human and financial resources, and difficulties in obtaining continuous and consistent data. However, glacier data collection specifically suffers from issues related to visual interpretation uncertainty and the lack of high-quality visible images in frequently cloudy or snow-covered regions, which may not be as prevalent in other natural monitoring scenarios.

Interpretation.Question: How do in-situ measurements and remote sensing techniques contribute to understanding glacier changes in China's western regions?
Interpretation.Answer: In-situ measurements and remote sensing are crucial for understanding glacier changes in China's western regions. In-situ measurements provide direct observation data of glacier mass balance and length, while remote sensing offers extensive coverage and temporal data to track glacier outlines and basic parameters. These methods help assess the spatial and temporal variations of glaciers and support the analysis of climatic and topographic influences on glacier evolution.

Interpretation.Question: What data collection methods could be utilized to enhance the understanding of glacier-induced water resource dynamics in international river basins?
Interpretation.Answer: To enhance understanding of glacier-induced water resource dynamics in international river basins, combining remote sensing data with in-situ hydrological measurements can be effective. This approach allows for detailed tracking of glacier meltwater contributions to river systems. Additionally, integrating global and regional glacier inventories with river basin boundary data can provide insights into the spatial distribution and effects of glacier meltwater on socioecological systems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the limited availability of long-term and continuous monitoring data for glaciers in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The inaccessibility of most glaciated areas and shortages of long-term human and financial resources contribute to the limited availability of long-term and continuous monitoring data for glaciers in China. Only a few glaciers have been observed, and very few have been continuously monitored as reference glaciers worldwide.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might there be discrepancies in glacier data between different inventory periods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Discrepancies in glacier data between different inventory periods could arise from the uncertainty of visual interpretation, leading to a lower estimate of retreat. Some glaciers emerged in the second Chinese Glacier Inventory (CGI-2) but were not available in the first inventory (CGI-1), due to updated real-time information and differences in data collection methods, such as using aerial photographs versus satellite images.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying causes behind the regional variations in glacier evolution observed in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The underlying causes behind the regional variations in glacier evolution observed in China include climatic conditions, such as annual mean temperature and precipitation, which are primary factors. A significant positive correlation is observed between snowfall variations and glacier changes, while rainfall variations show a negative correlation. However, there is no significant correlation between air temperature indicators and glacial changes at the river basin scale.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using aerial photographs and topographic maps from the 1960s to 1980s for glacier inventory data collection on the accuracy and reliability of glacier evolution analysis?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of aerial photographs and topographic maps from the 1960s to 1980s can affect the accuracy and reliability of glacier evolution analysis due to potential inaccuracies and limitations in historical data. These methods may not capture detailed changes over time, leading to uncertainties in visual interpretation and possibly resulting in a lower estimate of glacier retreat between periods.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the challenges of inaccessibility and limited long-term monitoring resources impact the development and refinement of glacier datasets in China?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The challenges of inaccessibility and limited long-term monitoring resources can result in only a few glaciers being observed or continuously monitored, which may hinder comprehensive data collection. This could lead to gaps in data, making it difficult to accurately track individual glacier evolution and potentially underestimating glacier retreat or changes over time.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to establish a one-to-one correspondence between glaciers from different Chinese Glacier Inventories to assess glacier changes over recent decades?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Establishing a one-to-one correspondence between glaciers from different inventories is crucial for conducting a spatially explicit and coherent national-scale assessment of glacier changes. This approach allows researchers to explore changes in area, volume, and Equilibrium Line Altitude (ELA) at both individual glacier and river basin scales, thereby illuminating the evolution and influencing factors of glacier dynamics over time.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can one establish a reliable correspondence between historical glacier datasets to assess changes in glacier areas and volumes over time?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: One can establish a reliable correspondence between historical glacier datasets by connecting glaciers individually from different inventory periods, like CGI-1 and CGI-2, using their boundaries and evolutionary trajectories. This involves removing outdated glacier data and creating one-to-one mappings to track changes in area, volume, and other parameters at both individual glacier and river basin scales.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the integration of glacier distribution data with watershed boundary data for effective glacier impact assessments?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of glacier distribution data with watershed boundary data in this field has been enabled by advancements such as remote sensing technologies, including Landsat TM/ETM+, ASTER, and Google Earth images, as well as the development of datasets like the Randolph Glacier Inventory and HydroBASINS. These technologies and datasets allow for accurate intersection analysis to generate glacier-influenced watershed boundary data from 1950 to 2020.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or data collection strategies facilitate the accurate updating of glacier outlines and basic parameters for national glacier inventories?
Enablement.Answer: Accurate updating of glacier outlines and basic parameters for national glacier inventories is facilitated by the use of high-resolution satellite imagery, such as Landsat TM/ETM+ and ASTER, combined with ground-truthing through field investigations. These strategies help overcome challenges posed by frequent cloud cover or snow coverage in certain mountainous regions, ensuring that updated and reliable data are incorporated into inventories like CGI-2.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in continuously monitoring glacier changes in China's western regions?
Expectation.Answer: Due to the inaccessibility of most glaciated areas and shortages of long-term human and financial resources, only a few glaciers have been observed and very few glaciers have been continuously monitored as reference glaciers in the world.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reasons behind the emergence of unobserved glaciers in new inventories that were not present in earlier datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Some glaciers emerged in new inventories, but statistics were not available for earlier datasets because of the uncertainty of visual interpretation, which may have led to a lower estimate of retreat.

Expectation.Question: How might climatic conditions influence the spatiotemporal patterns of glacier changes observed in datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Climatic conditions, as reflected in annual mean temperature and precipitation, are the primary causes of different spatiotemporal patterns of glacier change. A significant positive correlation is observed between annual absolute area/volume changes and snowfall variations, and a significant negative correlation is found with rainfall variations.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using remote sensing and modeling techniques for monitoring glacier changes in China and surrounding regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Remote sensing and modeling techniques have been effectively used to monitor glacier changes in China, providing valuable data on the retreating trends observed in the past half-century. These methods allow for the assessment of area, volume, and Equilibrium Line Altitude (ELA) changes at both individual glacier and river basin scales, despite challenges in accessing certain glaciated areas.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the primary challenges faced in maintaining continuous long-term monitoring of glaciers in the western regions of China?
Judgmental.Answer: The primary challenges in maintaining continuous long-term monitoring of glaciers in western China include the inaccessibility of most glaciated areas and shortages of long-term human and financial resources. Additionally, the frequent cloud cover and snow in specific regions hinder the acquisition of high-quality visible images, which complicates data collection efforts.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how researchers manage to establish a correspondence between glaciers from different periods, given the challenges in accessing glaciated areas.
Assertion.Answer: Researchers establish a correspondence between glaciers from different periods by removing glaciers with outdated information and then matching the remaining glaciers based on evolutionary trajectories. This involves analyzing glacier boundaries from the first and second Chinese Glacier Inventories (CGI-1 and CGI-2) and discriminating different types of glacier evolution.

Assertion.Question: I can't comprehend how the influence of climatic factors is determined in the context of glacier changes over such a large spatial scale.
Assertion.Answer: Climatic factors are determined by analyzing variations in annual mean temperature and precipitation, which are correlated with changes in glacier area, volume, and Equilibrium Line Altitude (ELA). A significant positive correlation is observed between snowfall variations and glacier changes, while a negative correlation is noted with rainfall variations, explaining the spatiotemporal patterns of glacier change.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used to compile glacier inventories in China over recent decades and discuss their evolution.
Request/Directive.Answer: The Chinese Glacier Inventories (CGI-1 and CGI-2) were compiled using different methods over the decades. CGI-1 was based on aerial photographs and topographic maps from the 1960s to the 1980s, combined with extensive field investigations. CGI-2 updated glacier outlines using satellite imagery from Landsat TM/ETM+, ASTER, and Google Earth images from 2004 to 2011.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify the challenges faced in monitoring glacier changes in China and discuss how these challenges influence data availability and reliability.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in monitoring glacier changes include the inaccessibility of many glaciated areas and shortages of long-term human and financial resources, leading to limited continuous monitoring. This affects data availability and reliability as very few glaciers have been observed continuously, and uncertainties in visual interpretation may lead to lower estimates of retreat.
